edu.umn.nlpnewt

Class Document

  • java.lang.Object
    • edu.umn.nlpnewt.Document

  • public class Document
extends java.lang.Object
    A document of text and labels in the NEWT system.

    Documents are stored on accessed via creation or retrieval on an Event object using Event.addDocument(String, String) or Event.getDocuments().

    Documents are keyed by their name, this is to allow pipelines to store different pieces of related text on a single processing event. An example would be storing the text of one language on one document, and the text of another language on another, or, for example, storing the plaintext.

    Both label indices, once added, and the document text are immutable. This is to enable parallelization and distribution of processing, and to prevent changes to upstream data that has already been used in the creation of downstream data.

      • getLabeler

        @ExperimentalApi
 @NotNull
public <L extends Label> @NotNull Labeler<L> getLabeler(@NotNull
                                                                                   @NotNull java.lang.String labelIndexName,
                                                                                   @NotNull
                                                                                   @NotNull ProtoLabelAdapter<L> adapter)
        Returns a labeler for the type specified by <L> to the label index keyed by labelIndexName using adapter to perform message adapting.

        Example: 

             
     try (Labeler<GenericLabel> labeler = document.getLabeler("sentences", Sentence.ADAPTER)) {
        labeler.add(GenericLabel.newBuilder(0, 22).build());
        labeler.add(GenericLabel.newBuilder(33, 55).build());
        labeler.add(GenericLabel.newBuilder(56, 88).build());
     }
        Type Parameters:
        L - The label type.
        Parameters:
        labelIndexName - The label index name that the labels will be uploaded to.
        adapter - The adapter.
        Returns:
        Labeler object.
        See Also:
        ProtoLabelAdapter

      • getLabeler

        @NotNull
public @NotNull Labeler<GenericLabel> getLabeler(@NotNull
                                                          @NotNull java.lang.String labelIndexName)
        Returns a labeler for non-distinct GenericLabel objects stored on labelIndexName.

        Example: 

         try (Labeler<GenericLabel> labeler = document.getLabeler("pos_tags")) {
   labeler.add(GenericLabel.newBuilder(0, 4).setProperty("tag", "NOUN").build());
   labeler.add(GenericLabel.newBuilder(5, 9).setProperty("tag", "VERB").build());
   labeler.add(GenericLabel.newBuilder(10, 12).setProperty("tag", "ADP").build());
   labeler.add(GenericLabel.newBuilder(13, 16).setProperty("tag", "DET").build());
   labeler.add(GenericLabel.newBuilder(17, 22).setProperty("tag", "NOUN").build());
        Parameters:
        labelIndexName - The index name to store the labels under.
        Returns:
        Labeler object, must be "closed" to send labels to server.

      • getLabeler

        @NotNull
public @NotNull Labeler<GenericLabel> getLabeler(@NotNull
                                                          @NotNull java.lang.String labelIndexName,
                                                          boolean isDistinct)
        Returns a labeler for GenericLabel objects stored on labelIndexName with distinctness specified by isDistinct.

        The technical definition of distinctness is that there is an ordering of the labels in the index in which the zipped start indices and end indices is non-decreasing, and there are no labels of length 0.

        Example: 

             
     try (Labeler<GenericLabel> labeler = document.getLabeler("sentences", true)) {
        labeler.add(GenericLabel.newBuilder(0, 22).build());
        labeler.add(GenericLabel.newBuilder(33, 55).build());
        labeler.add(GenericLabel.newBuilder(56, 88).build());
     }
        Parameters:
        labelIndexName - The index name.
        isDistinct - true if the labels are distinct (non-overlapping), false otherwise.
        Returns:
        Labeler object.

      • getCreatedIndices

        @NotNull
public @NotNull java.util.List<java.lang.String> getCreatedIndices()
        The list of the names of all label indices that have been added to this document locally.
        Returns:
        An unmodifiable list of index names that have been added to this document.
